#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Get Prepared to Be a Bookworm
#Text=Have you ever procrastinated about reading books or ever wanted to be a writer , but ending up feeling like giving up on one of these things ?
#Text=Have you ever wanted to be a great writer like J.K. Rowling , Shakespeare , Charles Dickens , Emily Dickinson , C.S. Lewis , J.R.R. Tolkien , Jane Austen , Mark Twain , or even L. Frank Baum ?
#Text=Here 's a few ordinary steps for you on becoming a bookworm .
#Text=Starting to act towards your goal to actually become a great writer like these super amazing authors will also make you a pretty good reader .
#Text=Here are 4 steps to get into the habit of reading , writing , and become a bookworm !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Take out a fresh notebook or calendar ( any special one that you have in store at home/ buy one at Target , Walmart , Staples , etc. ) and get out a pen or pencil .
#Text=Make sure to stick to that notebook ( the reason why I want you all to get out a notebook is because you must write down your goals and other things I 'll cover up while making these steps ) .
#Text=Write your first and last name in the front or back of your notebook .
#Text=Write down any ideas for books/ formulate an idea section .
#Text=Make sure to write down at least 1 or more goals ( whether it be mini goals or enormous ones )
#Text=example : I want to ride a bike at least 2 times per week or I want to write a novel and leave at least 2 hours to write things about the book and do some research on it .
#Text=it can be whatever way you want it to turn out .
#Text=This can take about 1-10 minutes to do .
#Text=Remember , one of your goals must be related to reading books and/or writing .
#Text=For example , be specific about how many books you want to read in a year ( you must do the math sadly ... . ) and begin with very easy books ( something that fits your age ) .
#Text=Start to get into the habit of going to the library and check out books .
#Text=This can help you figure out what subject or what genre you appreciate .
#Text=You can also find new friends with shared interests while you are there .
#Text=Befriend the librarian , and simply look in the back of the books to read the description about the book to get the gist of the story .
#Text=Do online research too .
#Text=Log on to websites like sparknotes.com or goodreads.com to know more about the book/books you are currently reading or the one that you plan to buy .
#Text=Read about the author and watch video interviews of the authors you admire .
#Text=You can catch their reasons to write and know what were their inspirations .
#Text=If you can relate to something they say , write it down in your notebook .
#Text=If you feel up to it , you can even start fan fiction about your favorite characters .
#Text=It helps you collect feedback and track your progress via comments from other fans of the work you derive your fan fiction from .
#Text=Keep a dictionary handy .
#Text=If you do n't understand a part or word in the book , do n't wait ask a friend online what it means unless you can look it up on your own .
#Text=Religiously collect new words/phrases , plot-points/ideas , character quirks that stick to you in the book .
#Text=You will be amazed at how quick your notebook will fill up .
#Text=If you have read so far and is thus serious about becoming a writer , never be ashamed to try out the classes in High School or College towards becoming an aspiring writer .
#Text=Remember that becoming published and setting up a writing studio are all a lot cheaper now with e-books and e-readers galore .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Read books that will inspire you in the future
#Text=this requires a notebook

#Text=Read as much as you want and write a good 1-5 sentence summary of each chapter ( if it does have chapters ) or when you feel like not reading , write a list of things that relate to the book ( maybe this might help you come up with your own writing ideas in the future )
#Text=Never shy away from poetry and listen to instrumental music when you read your novels .

#Text=( Studies suggest that listening to soft classical music like Bach , Mozart , Beethoven , Brahms , etc. , will help you concentrate on what you read be it right before you go to bed or upon waking up in the morning .
